title: 109_s117
content: Loan forgiveness for Head Start teachers. The "Loan Forgiveness for Head Start Teachers Act of 2005" allows Head Start teachers who have worked full-time for 5 consecutive years to qualify for loan forgiveness. Teachers must also meet certain qualifications to be eligible for this program. The "Loan Forgiveness for Head Start Teachers Act of 2005" allows eligible Head Start teachers to qualify for loan forgiveness after working full-time for 5 consecutive years. Teachers must demonstrate knowledge and teaching skills in various areas of preschool curriculum, with a focus on cognitive learning. Eligibility for loan forgiveness is contingent upon receiving a baccalaureate or graduate degree on or after the enactment of the Act in 2005. The Higher Education Act of 1965 allows for loan repayment for teachers who have worked full-time for 5 consecutive years in qualifying schools. The Higher Education Act of 1965 allows for loan forgiveness for teachers who have worked full-time for 5 consecutive years in qualifying schools, including Head Start teachers who meet specific qualifications. The Higher Education Act of 1965 allows for loan forgiveness for teachers who have worked full-time for 5 consecutive years in qualifying schools, including Head Start teachers who meet specific qualifications. The Act also authorizes appropriations for loan repayment for service described in subsection (b)(1)(A)(i) for fiscal year 2009 and beyond. Amendments to the FFEL program include extending loan forgiveness eligibility to the fifth complete program year of teaching. The Higher Education Act of 1965 allows for loan forgiveness for teachers who have worked full-time for 5 consecutive years in qualifying schools. Amendments to the Act extend loan forgiveness eligibility to the fifth complete program year of teaching. Amendments to the Higher Education Act extend loan forgiveness eligibility to the fifth complete program year of teaching by making specific changes to subsections (g)(1)(A) and (h).
